blueprints.title: Define Your Product in 30 Seconds
blueprints.scenario: You have a great app idea but can't explain it clearly. What's your elevator pitch?
blueprints.context: Tool: A mobile app that finds nearby coffee shops based on your mood (wants: strong espresso, vibe: quiet, budget: cheap)
blueprints.task: Create a 30-second pitch that answers: What is it? Who is it for? Why should they care?
blueprints.exampleWeak: 'An app for finding coffee shops. It uses your mood to find places. Pretty cool.'
blueprints.exampleStrong: 'Tired of scrolling through mediocre coffee reviews? CoffeeMatch uses AI to find the perfect shop in 10 seconds based on YOUR mood right now. Strong shots or cozy vibes? It knows. Available for iOS and Android.'
blueprints.framework: Problem → Solution (you solve it) → Why now (timing/proof) → Call to action (try it)

blueprints.title: Map Your User Journey
blueprints.scenario: You need to understand every step a customer takes from discovery to becoming a paying user.
blueprints.context: SaaS tool: AI-powered scheduling assistant for busy executives

stages.name: Awareness
stages.question: How do they hear about you?
stages.example: LinkedIn ad, Twitter, word of mouth

stages.name: Consideration
stages.question: What do they need to believe?
stages.example: It actually saves time, integrates with Outlook, won't miss meetings

stages.name: Decision
stages.question: What's the final blocker?
stages.example: Will my team use it? Can I try free first?

stages.name: Onboarding
stages.question: How do they get value in first 10 mins?

blueprints.task: For your product idea: Map each stage. What message matters at each stage?

blueprints.title: Build Your Feature Prioritization Matrix
blueprints.scenario: You have 20 feature ideas but can only build 3 this quarter. Which 3?
blueprints.context: Project management app. Features: Dark mode, AI task breakdown, Slack integration, calendar sync, mobile app, API, templates, time tracking, custom fields, etc.
blueprints.framework: Score each feature on: (1) User demand (how many want it?), (2) Business impact (revenue impact?), (3) Effort (months to build?). Keep features with high demand + high impact + low effort.
blueprints.task: Pick your top 5 features and score them. Build a priority list based on demand × impact ÷ effort.

blueprints.title: Design Your Monetization Strategy
blueprints.scenario: You're ready to charge. How do you price? What's your model?
blueprints.context: B2B SaaS tool. Customers range from 5-person teams to 500-person enterprises. Some just need basics, others need everything.

options.pros: Fair for large teams, scales with usage
options.cons: Small teams price-sensitive, hard to grow

options.pros: Aligns value with price, no limits
options.cons: Hard to forecast revenue, unpredictable for customer
Some users gap between tiers, needs 3 tiers to optimize
options.bestFor: Most SaaS (if you don't know what to do, use this)

options.pros: Customer pays based on ROI they get
options.cons: Hard to measure, risky, only works for very high-value products
options.bestFor: Sales tools where ROI is obvious

blueprints.task: For your product: Which model fits best? Design your pricing tiers/structure.

blueprints.title: Build Your MVP Specification
blueprints.scenario: You're building an MVP (minimum viable product) with limited resources. What's absolutely essential?
blueprints.context: New AI note-taking app idea. Dream features: AI summarization, voice notes, handwriting recognition, team collaboration, smart linking, version history, advanced search, API, mobile app, desktop app, web app, browser extension.
blueprints.framework: Ruthless prioritization: Keep only features that (1) directly solve core problem, (2) get users to value quickly, (3) can be built in 4-6 weeks. Everything else is nice-to-have post-launch.

mvsExample.why: Get to market fast. Prove people want it.

blueprints.task: For your product: List all features. Pick your 5 MVP features. Be ruthless—if it can ship in v2, it goes in v2.

blueprints.title: Create Your Success Metrics Dashboard
blueprints.scenario: How do you know if your product is actually working? What do you measure?
blueprints.context: Productivity SaaS. You track: DAU (daily active users), retention (% coming back), NPS (customer satisfaction), COGS (cost to serve), LTV (customer lifetime value), CAC (cost to acquire), churn rate, etc.
blueprints.framework: Pick ONE north star metric (what you optimize for) + 3-4 supporting metrics that predict success.

example.why: If users use it daily, they get value and stay longer
supporting: Time spent in-app (are they actually using it?)

blueprints.task: Define your north star metric. What ONE metric best shows if you're succeeding? Pick 3 supporting metrics that predict long-term success.

blueprints.title: Design Your Go-to-Market Strategy
blueprints.scenario: You've built an amazing product. Now what? How do you get customers at scale?
blueprints.context: You're launching a design tool for non-designers. You have: $50K budget, 3-person team, 6 months until next funding.
blueprints.task: Pick 2-3 channels for your product. Explain WHY they fit. Create a 6-month plan showing which channels you'll pursue each month.

blueprints.title: Competitive Positioning Blueprint
blueprints.scenario: There are 50 competitors doing what you're doing (or close). How do you win?
blueprints.context: You're building a password manager. Competitors: 1Password, Bitwarden, LastPass, Dashlane, etc.
blueprints.framework: Positioning = (1) Target customer (who specifically?), (2) Problem we solve (what's wrong with alternatives?), (3) Our unique approach (how are we different?), (4) Proof/credibility (why should you trust us?).

example.target: Engineering teams who value security and control
example.problem: Password managers are slow, black boxes you have to trust blindly
example.approach: Open-source, self-hosted, built by security researchers. YOU control the data.
example.proof: Used by 1000+ security-conscious companies. Code audited by independent firms.

blueprints.task: Define your competitive position. Who's your target? What's wrong with alternatives? How are you different? What's your proof?

blueprints.title: Build Your 90-Day Roadmap
blueprints.scenario: You're launching a product in 90 days. What's your plan month-by-month?
blueprints.context: You've got team, funding, and a clear vision. You need a roadmap.
blueprints.framework: Month 1: Polish core product, get early users. Month 2: Get feedback, iterate, hit product-market fit signals. Month 3: Scale marketing, optimize conversion, prepare for growth.

exampleMonth1.marketing: Launch on ProductHunt, organic community, influencers

blueprints.task: Create your 90-day plan. For each month: What's the goal? What features? What's your marketing strategy? How do you measure success?

blueprints.title: Present Your Full Blueprint
blueprints.scenario: You have 10 minutes to pitch your product to investors. What's your slide deck?

slides.title: Problem
slides.content: What's broken? Why does it matter? Who feels this pain?

slides.title: Solution
slides.content: What's your product? Why is it different? Show demo or prototype.

slides.title: Market
slides.content: How big is this? TAM (total addressable market). Who's the target?

slides.title: Traction
slides.content: Proof it works. Users, revenue, testimonials, press. (Or: 'Pre-launch MVP' if new)

slides.title: Business Model
slides.content: How do you make money? Pricing? Margins? Unit economics?

slides.title: Team
slides.content: Who's building it? Why are you the right team?

slides.title: Ask
slides.content: How much funding? What will you do with it?

blueprints.task: Create your 7-slide pitch deck outline. For each slide, write the core message (1-2 sentences). Be compelling.
